section.title: Gateways & Auth Brokers cannot be installed on a cloud statement
section.note: Because API Gateways and Authentication Brokers can be installed only as a single-tenant, API Gateways and Authentication Brokers can be leveraged only in the account that they are installed in and cannot be shared across accounts.

section.title: Installation directory
section.ph: If you previously upgraded to a new Java version, copy the full <installation_directory>/jre directory and the full install4j folder to different locations before running the upgrader.

section.title: Java version rollback
section.p:
If a problem occurred during the update and you need to roll back to your prior version of Java, do the following:
If you previously ran the upgrader, move the new <installation_directory>/jre folder to another location. Then, replace it with the original <installation_directory>/jre folder that you copied before starting the upgrade.
Whether or not you previously ran the upgrader, update the install4j folder to use the prior version of Java as described in the topic Making an Atom, Molecule, or Atom Cloud use a different Java version. After you have resolved the upgrade issues that caused you to roll back to your prior version of Java, upgrade the Atom or Molecule again.

section.title: Installers — task topic prereqs

p.ph: Java 8 JRE or the Java 11 JDK.

section.p: Cloud Molecules require the Java 8 JRE or the Java 11 JDK. Java 11 is recommended. internally tested Oracle Java 1.8.0_302 and Amazon Corretto OpenJDK 11.0.12.7.1.

If you do not have Java 11 installed on your machine, you can download the installer file that includes a private copy of Java 11 (11.0.12.7.1) from Atom Atom Management . You can alternatively manage your own distribution of the Java 11 JDK by downloading the JDK here prior to installing the Cloud Molecule.Make sure that the Java binary that is used to run the installer comes from the <jdk>/jre/bin directory and not the <jdk>/bin directory.

The installer will install a private copy of Java 11 (11.0.12.7.1) for the Atom to use. You can alternatively manage your own distribution of the Java 11 JDK by downloading the JDK here prior to installing the Atom.

The installer will install a private copy of Java 11 (11.0.12.7.1) for the Molecule to use. You can alternatively manage your own distribution of the Java 11 JDK by downloading the JDK here prior to installing the Molecule.
section.note: Java 11 does not officially support 32-bit execution, so 32-bit installers are not provided.

If you are managing your own Java version instead of using the distribution provided by , Molecules that will use forked execution require the Java 8 JDK rather than the JRE. Since Java 11 is distributed as a JDK by default, no additional consideration should be required if using Java 11.

section.title: Atom naming convention
section.note: The following characters are reserved and cannot be used in the name: asterisk (*), backslash (\), caret (^), colon (:), dollar sign ($), greater than (>), less than (<), percent (%), pipe (|), question mark (?), quotation mark ("), slash mark (/), Yen sign (¥).

note.p: Anti-virus programs that scan the installation folder of your Atoms, Molecules, and Atom Clouds might conflict with their operation. If the anti-virus program attempts to access the files while your Atom, Molecule, or Atom Cloud is running, it can cause conflicts. Also, the anti-virus program could cause permission issues by being seen as a different user.
Therefore, disable the anti-virus program from running against the Atom, Molecule, or Atom Cloud installation folder.

Or, program the anti-virus program to run on the Atom, Molecule, and Atom Cloud installation folders during planned maintenance windows. Once the anti-virus program has been run, check the anti-virus quarantine folder for any valid files that may have been incorrectly quarantined.

section.title: Unsupported operating systems
section.p: does not officially support installations on Unix operating systems. Because Unix is not officially tested or supported by , the Support team will be unable to troubleshoot or support any Unix-related issues.

section.title: Minimum hardware requirements
section.p: A single Atom, Molecule node, or Cloud Molecule within an Atom Cloud can run on hardware ranging from business-class workstations to dedicated servers.

row.entry: 2 GB RAM (minimum 1 GB dedicated to Atom, Molecule node, or Cloud Molecule)
50 MB for run-time and configuration, 10 GB for data archiving

section.title: Minimum hardware requirements for high volumes of data
section.p: A single Atom, Molecule node, or Cloud Molecule within an Atom Cloud that must process high volumes of data has these requirements.

row.entry:
Dual 64-bit processors or higher
More processors allow for increased, simultaneous process executions

More RAM allows for increased, simultaneous process executions

section.title: Minimum software requirements for Windows and Linux

row.entry:
Java 8 or 11 is required. Java 11 is recommended.
internally tested Java versions 1.8.0_302 and 11.0.12.7.1.

The Atom, Molecule, or Atom Cloud is a Java application and requires Java 8 or 11 to run.
For Java 8, supports only the Oracle (formerly Sun) Java Runtime. The installer automatically downloads a private copy of the Java 8 JDK for the Atom, Molecule, or Atom Cloud's use.
For Java 11, supports only the Amazon Corretto Java Runtime. The Java 11 runtime is automatically provided in the JDK that is downloaded when you install a new runtime container.The Java 11 installer downloads a private copy of the JDK. You can continue to use Java 8 installer files previously downloaded on your local drive to install runtime containers on Java 8. Depending on which version you install, the Java 8 JRE or the Java 11 JDK are placed in your Atom’s or Molecule’s jre directory. The private JRE or JDK will not interfere with a shared JRE or JDK (one that you, not the installer, installed). It is not integrated into browsers and does not write registry entries.

section.title: Numbers of machines required
section.p: The minimum number of machines required for operation is two:

li.p: One shared file server
One Molecule node or Cloud Molecule

section.p: The minimum number of machines required for full failover is four:

li.p: One shared file server
One backup shared file server
Two Molecule nodes or Cloud Molecules

section.note:
To prepare for failover, you should keep one Molecule offline but mirror the primary Molecule to the secondary one on a regular basis. For more information about backup and disaster recovery best practices, review the following resources in the Community:
Best Practices for Run Time High Availability and Disaster Recovery knowledge article
Backup and Disaster Recovery video

section.title: Operating system requirements
section.p: All nodes in a Molecule, or Cloud Molecules in an Atom Cloud, must be running on the same operating system. For example, you cannot run one of the Molecule's nodes on Windows and another of its nodes on Linux.

It is recommended that all nodes in a Molecule, or Cloud Molecules in an Atom Cloud, use the same operating system architecture, i.e., all should be on Windows 32-bit machines or all should be on Windows 64-bit machines.

section.title: Hardware requirements
section.p: All nodes in a Molecule, or Cloud Molecules in an Atom Cloud, do not have to be installed on computers with the same hardware configuration. The machines can have different amounts of RAM, a different type of CPU, etc.

section.title: File system requirements
section.p: The primary requirement for running a Molecule or Atom Cloud is that all nodes or Cloud Molecules that are part of it must be using the same installation directory.

Because the main use for clustering is to allow multiple machines to work together, this means that there is some form of shared file system in use. Due to the implementation of the Molecule and Atom Cloud support within the Atom, this file system must support file locking. Common examples of this are:

li.p: An NFS file system with NFS locking enabled (NLM support)
A Windows network share or drive

section.note: The file system is required to have the same OS and architecture as all nodes in a Molecule or Cloud Molecules in an Atom Cloud, otherwise file locking issues may occur. SMB/CIFS is recommended for Windows machines. NFS is recommended for Linux machines.

section.title: Network recommendations
section.p: For best performance, the various machines in a Molecule or Atom Cloud should have multicast (UDP) available between them. However, this is not a requirement, because the clustering protocol can be configured to work in a unicast-only (TCP) environment. See more information about network configuration for Molecules and Atom Clouds.

li.p: If you are installing a Cloud Molecule or a Molecule node that will use forked execution, you must install a JDK or use the -provided Java from installation. We currently do not support any other JDK. The current supported versions are:
Oracle's Java SE Development Kit 8u302, if you are installing on Linux or Windows
Amazon Corretto's Java SE Development Kit 11.0.12, if you are installing on Linux or Windows

It is recommended that all machines in the Molecule or Atom Cloud have the same version of Java installed. Java must be located in the same directory on each machine (i.e., C:/Program Files/Java/jre8 for Windows or /usr/local/java for Linux).

ul.li:
Java 11 installations and upgrades automatically provide the full JDK complete with the JRE. If you use Molecules or Clouds with forked executions and manage your own Java 8 version, keep the following in mind:
If you do not wish to upgrade to Java 11, you do not need to install a separate JDK to use forked executions as they are already provided in the -supplied JDK.
If you do not wish to upgrade to Java 11 and choose to use a version of Java not provided by , ensure that you download the JDK and not the JRE.

section.title: Firewall rules
section.p: The nodes need to communicate with each other in order to cluster successfully.

li.p: If you are using multicast defaults, port 45588 must be open.
If you are using unicast defaults, port 7800 must be open.

section.title: Host setup
section.p: Ensure that the host names of the machines resolve to valid IP addresses, not to the localhost adapter, which is 127.0.0.1.

section.title: Purge data setting
section.note:
If an Atom Cloud owner has set purge data in the Atom Cloud to:
ON — the setting affects all Atoms attached to this Atom Cloud. Accounts that own Atoms attached to this Atom Cloud can turn off their Atom’s setting, but it is overridden by the Atom Cloud’s setting.
OFF — accounts with an Atom attached to the Atom Cloud can set purge as needed for their Atom and the Atom’s setting is not overridden by the Atom Cloud’s setting. A change to this setting takes effect immediately — the Atom Cloud does not need to be restarted.

section.title: Shared Web Server logs
section.note: If you select a date outside the valid date range, a warning message appears. You can change the date or keep it. In some cases you might need to select a date outside the range. For example, you and your Atom could be located in different time zones. If processes ran early on Thursday morning, but where you are located it is still late Wednesday evening, you could legitimately need to download “tomorrow’s” logs today. If no logs are available for the selected date, a message appears.

section.title: ACM ownership
section.note: If your account does not own the selected Atom, Molecule, or Atom Cloud, or if the selected Atom is attached to an Atom Cloud, the Scheduling panel is not visible to you.

section.title: AS2 messages
section.note: Log file paths contain AS2 message IDs, which can be relatively long. In a Windows environment, be aware of the maximum system path length limit of 260 characters when specifying the path to which to save the .zip file.

li.p: All communication from the Atom to the data center uses TLS encryption. We support TLS version 1.1 and TLS version 1.2. SSL version 3.0 has been disabled due to the Poodle vulnerability.

section.title: Atom Management Read Access
section.p: You must have the Atom Management privilege to perform this task. If you have the Atom Management Read Access privilege, you cannot perform the task.

section.note: On March 28, 2018, disabled support for TLS v1.0 on the EU and ANZ Atom Clouds and all Hub Clouds. On May 23, 2018, additionally disabled support for TLS v1.0 on the and the US Atom Cloud. On October 29, 2021, disabled support for TLS v1.0 for Atoms and Molecules.

li.p: Make sure the nfslock daemon is enabled at startup and is running on the NFS client nodes.
Make sure this central storage is mounted in the same path on all nodes and that the Molecule or Atom Cloud service account has write access to the path.
Make sure users and groups are correctly identified across mounts. Viewing file details in NFS mounted directories should display valid user and group names.
In NFSv4, this is often controlled by the idmapd daemon. Ensure this is enabled and running on each node and NFS server.
Leverage mount options that support binary execution via the share.
NFS client /etc/fstab example: vers=3,noatime,nodiratime,rw,hard,intr,bg,addr=nfsserver.domain.com
vers= — Specifies the NFS version the server must support. This option may not be necessary, depending on the client/server setup.
noatime — Disables “access time” tracking on files. This information is generally unnecessary to maintain and can waste nontrivial IO bandwidth.
nodiratime — This is the same as noatime except for directories.
rw — Read and write access is required by the Atom.
hard — Requires NFS client operations to complete. Not using this option may cause silent data corruption.
intr — Allows signals to interrupt NFS operations. This will prevent the system from hanging if the NFS server stops responding.
bg — Allows the system to start up even if the initial NFS mount fails. This will prevent the system from hanging on startup if the NFS server is not yet available.
addr= — The address used for servers with multiple IP subnets on the same interface. Usually this setting is not needed.
If you are using NFSv4, bind mounts are required in order to function.
NFS server /etc/fstab example: /data/boomi/exports/data/boomi none bind 0 0
NFS Server /etc/exports example: /exports <ipaddr/32>(rw,insecure,no_subtree_check,nohide,fsid=0,sync,no_root_squash)

section.title: Synchronize clocks and time zones
section.p: Ensure that the clock on all Molecule nodes, including central storage services (e.g., NFS), are synchronized regularly using something like NTP. If the clocks on the machines are not closely synchronized, you are likely to encounter problems with: the clustering protocol, accurate time recording for cross-node actions, and accurate handling of files on the shared file system.

Ensure that all machines are set to use the same time zone. This includes the machines on which the Molecule nodes run, as well as file servers being used. See your operating system’s documentation for instructions on how to set your machines’ time zone.

section.title: Consider failover and disaster recovery needs
section.p: For information about backup and disaster recovery best practices for Molecules and Atom Clouds, review the following resources in the Community:

p.xref: Best Practices for Run Time High Availability and Disaster Recovery knowledge article

section.p: If you usually take point-in-time snapshots of your systems with a tool such as VMware, there is no need to take snapshots of the nodes in a Molecule or Atom Cloud. The nodes do not contain any valuable information beyond operating system settings. However, if you want to take a snapshot of a Molecule or Atom Cloud node, do so only once at setup time and before starting the node.
section.note: does not recommend taking snapshots of Molecule or Atom Cloud nodes on an ongoing basis. Doing so can negatively impact the node's operational stability.

section.title: Scripting Engines
section.note:
The scripting engine that is used depends on whether you use Windows or Linux. If you are running:
Windows and an Atom, or if you are running a Molecule that does not use UNC paths or forked execution, then batch scripts (.bat) are used.
Windows and a Molecule that uses UNC paths or forked execution, or if you are running an Atom Cloud, then Powershell scripts (.ps1) are used.
Linux, then shell scripts (.sh) are used in all situations.

section.title: Docker
section.note:
The use of Docker to install and maintain a local Atom, Molecule, or Atom Cloud is a Tech Preview not intended for production use. Your feedback is welcome.
Docker support is an optional account feature. If you would like to have this feature enabled in your account, contact your representative.

section.title: AWS
section.p: The Boomi Molecule on AWS Quick Start can reduce hundreds of manual procedures into just a few steps, so customers can build a Boomi Molecule production environment quickly and can start using it immediately. The Boomi Molecule AWS Quick Start includes a reference architecture, as well as a deployment guide, providing easy to understand instructions on how to deploy a fully functioning Boomi Molecule cluster on AWS in less than 30 minutes. To get started, go to the Boomi Molecule on AWS Quick Start. There are AWS credits available to cover the cost of initial POC and trial deployments based on approval. Contact Boomi.AWS.Team@dell.com to learn more about getting started and also visit the Boomi Community Article Deploy a Boomi Molecule Cluster on AWS with One Click.

section.title: Questions and answers about

p.uicontrol: Is the considered a release candidate or beta release?

section.p: The is neither a beta release or a release candidate, but rather it is an official release. A release candidate (or beta release) is a version of the release that allows customers to test features and report defects, which are then prioritized and fixed in time for the full release. Any issues related to the should be reported via Support as normal but are fixed as part of the regular development cycle for inclusion in a future release.

p.uicontrol: How can I know what features and fixes are or are not available in the ?

section.p: With each Runtime Release, provides release notes which list the features and fixes included in 's .

p.uicontrol: How do I know when updates are available prior to the ?

section.p: A system message appears in when updates are available. You also can check the Atom & Connector Versions panel in the service, or the Gateway version and Broker Version panels in the service to see if pending updates are listed for the respective runtime containers. See the Applying the section of this topic for more information.
Additionally, the Runtime Release schedule is also posted on the Notifications page.

p.uicontrol: Who is able to apply the updates?

section.p: To apply updates to Atoms, Molecules, or Clouds, users with the Atom Management privilege (typically users with the Administrator role) are able to apply the . You also must be authorized to update the selected Atom. You cannot apply updates to an Atom that you do not own, for example, a Atom Cloud.
To apply updates to API Gateways or Authentication Brokers, users with the privilege (typically users with the Administrator role) are able to apply the .

p.uicontrol: If I have multiple Atoms, do I have to update all of them at the same time?

section.p: No, you do not have to update all of your Atoms at once. You can individually update any Atom, Molecule, Atom Cloud, API Gateway or Authentication broker at your own leisure. Please see the Applying the section of this topic for more details.

p.uicontrol: Will the runtime containers be updated or rolled back immediately after I click the button to apply or to rollback updates?

section.p: The request is sent to the container immediately. Allow time for the updates or rollback to take effect. The container might restart during this process. It waits for a period of inactivity before applying the updates or rollback.

p.uicontrol: Can people use the platform while I apply the updates or a rollback?

section.p: Yes. Users who are logged into the platform are not affected.

p.uicontrol: Can updates be applied to or rolled back on a runtime container that is not currently running?

section.p: No. The updates or rollback will be applied to the container the next time it is started.

p.uicontrol: What happens if I don’t apply the updates prior to the ?

section.p: On the date, both the and updates are automatically applied to accounts.

section.title: About the
section.p:
The may include updates for the following runtime containers:
Atoms, Molecules, and Atom Clouds
API Gateways
Authentication Brokers
Specific Connectors

The typically occurs two weeks prior to the date. Applying the is an optional action; users can apply available updates at any point between the and until the . Users who opt not to apply the automatically receive all runtime updates on the date, which typically occurs on the second Saturday of each month.

Once the is applied to accounts automatically, all runtime containers are immediately restarted and may require downtime. To avoid disruption to your processes and configurations, you can apply the up to two weeks sooner and perform the mandatory restart of runtime containers at your own leisure.
